words.fact: Prudence requires accountants to be cautious and conservative when making estimates. Assets and revenues should not be overstated, while liabilities and expenses should not be understated.
Consistency requires using the same accounting methods from period to period. This allows stakeholders to compare financial statements across different time periods.
Sincerity demands that accountants provide an accurate and honest representation of the company's financial position. All information must be truthful and transparent.
Materiality means information should be disclosed if it could influence economic decisions of users. Immaterial items can be treated in a simpler, more cost-effective way.
Continuity assumes that the business will continue operating in the foreseeable future. This allows assets to be valued at cost rather than liquidation value.
